dialogues.Ted: Ted Hendricks. Vice President of Acquisitions.  Managing the acquisition. Identifying overlap. Reducing staff where we find redundancy. What's your focus been here, Gary?  Wow, okay. That's not...  No. What do you do?  Do you play an important role here?  I'm sorry. I was really getting into this song. What were you saying?    I'm not sure. But it's not at this time.  I have to see the board and start evaluations now.  I'll come by sometime this week.  How's the issue shaping up?  The photographer?  What does Quintessence mean?  Okay. Awesome.  (repeating to himself for  Who am I evaluating next?  This will only take a moment. I just wanted to inform you all, reluctantly, that this month's issue will be the last.  You are all valued employees. But as we undergo this transition we wanted to be candid with you that some of you will be--  (correcting him, a little    Most of them.  We wanted to be clear that most of you will be determined non-vital to the new partnership. The remaining few employees will carry over into the new organization. We'll be deciding which category your positions fall into over the course of the next week.  Now for some good news. We're very       Okay. So, we're very excited to play a part in publishing what will be the very last issue of Life Magazine, which has been an American Institution for 75 years and whose renowned covers have touched us all really touching ways. And for the final issue, our cover is going to be something which is... What was that word?  Our cover will probably be the most famous ever because it really has the awesome quintessence of Life. And we're all going to be a part of this historic happening. Even those of you who will, right after the happening, be asked to leave. Thank you.     Yes, sir. It's gone very smoothly. The last issue's underway. The cover? Yeah. It's amazing. It's so quintessence. It encapsulates majesty. Totally. It has some splendor, in it, too, probably. Also, I'm pretty sure it's illustrious and just really awesome. It took my breath away. And I haven't even seen it yet. We're getting it processed from practical assets now. Yes, sir. We're going to retain eleven employees. I'm going to be evaluating them over the next week.  You're vital here?  Why are you holding toys?  ...you wanted toys.  (nodding at Walter's  Yeah, you're toy.     (after being told it's  I know. Because I've been asking for it. Because it's the Quintessence fucking one that I told my boss we had. It's the cover. You seriously lost a photographer's work? At Life?  Why are you confident we'll find it?  That doesn't give me confidence, a no-answer. You're in assets, I guess?  This doesn't reflect very well on you.  During an evaluation week.  (gesturing out his cell  Don't Helmut Newton me.  Hey. We've held up publication of this issue because I told my boss that photo was fucking amazing. Okay? We've spent a hundred and nine thousand dollars because of the overage. You lost an amazing  Where is he?  Do you know what "fired with cause" means?  I have cause to fire you. You won't pick up another check. I can let you go without severance because-  You lost a Sean O'Connell. It was quintessence. He's a war photographer? Cubicle, you're going to tell this brave photographer, risks his life, that you, a male sitting in an office, lost--?  Do you work at one?  What are you named?  What's your name?  You're Walter Mitty?  Practical Assets.  Your pass key's not working because you've been let go. With cause.  Want to try the Four Seasons?

dialogues.Edna: Hi, honey.  Hi, Walter. Is it all right I'm dropping by?  Well, she's the artist...  I named her after a wonderful visit your Dad and I had to Odessa, our family's homeland, one summer, in southern Ukraine. There's a beautiful river there also named Odessa.  I named you after Walter Matthau  So the moving bill came, for my move down here. I wanted to bring it by. Thank you so much Walter.  Hi, Walter.  Oh, I'm just making some yogurt. With some banana.  It snowed today. Didn't expect that. Not much. Just a light little cover. Very pretty. Less than an inch even.  My piano got towed, Walter.  Yes. Odessa said it wasn't there. Where you said it was going to be.  She said possibly that it got towed. That that's not her space anymore.  Where are you, honey?  That's nice.  I just wanted to thank you for my Villa. Odessa told me all about it. It sounds so pleasant. Villa. That guy was a real dick.  Anyway, hon, you've really become the man of the family, and I wanted to say I love you, and Happy Birthday.  What a dick. Big man. Big warlord of the fortieth floor--  I was just discussing them. Last week. They rule over small areas of land using threats, and force bribes of livestock or klipspringers.  Yes.  In some parts of the world they carry small deer like we carry, say, quarters. To pay bribes. Also, blankets or clothing items like koofiyads.  Yes, for the warlords.  Yes?  Sean?  No. I took it. With Sean's camera.  From Sean. He came to visit.  He came to visit. To talk about you.  Yeah. He asked me some questions about you? What your work schedule was, when you left, when you came home. He said you really understood Life. He wanted to know about your work. He said you "got Life."  I just sent him my recipe for Clementine cake? To his email. I packed him some when he left. He just loved it. We snacked on some during our Warlord conversation.  He's in Nepal now, I think. Photographing snow leopards. Let me think. Yes. Ship. Iceland. Mogadishu. Nepal. That's what he said.  I didn't know that. You don't talk about work that often.  I was concerned we couldn't keep it, Dear. I know it's a burden. I didn't know if we could manage. So I thought I might not see it again. I wanted a picture.  That's not a very good picture. But that's okay. She's right here.  You know, I wonder sometimes... you had to start work so early. Orange Julius. Then all through college. At Avis. Then Pizza delivery. That shitty pizza. Then at this company.  I wish maybe you had the chance, a greater chance to pursue your dreams.  What did you want to be, when you younger?  Sure you do. Everybody does.  Thanks for taking care of us, Walter.
dialogues.Female: It's a tense environment. To be sure. There are fears of a repeat of the violence in Seattle at the WTO. And there are three thousand more protestors here today.  There's an outdoor concert scheduled just a block away from the hotel where the summit is held, which summit organizers say is a deliberate provocation, but which concert promoters and protestors say is within their freedom to assemble.

description: The manager of the negative-assets sector of Life magazine, Walter Mitty, has been working for 16 years for the magazine and has a tedious life, not going anywhere but to and from work. He is an escapist, daydreaming into a fantasy world many times a day. Walter has a crush on recently-hired Cheryl Melhoff but he is too shy to invite her out and he is trying to contact her via online dating. The magazine is preparing to release its last printed edition and the loathsome manager of transition Ted Hendricks is preparing an inevitable downsizing over the next few days. Walter has been the liaison between the magazine and the mysterious independent photographer Sean O'Connell, who has sent to him a package of negatives and a wallet as a gift for his work. Sean also suggests to the senior management the use of negative 25 for the cover of the last edition. However, Walter cannot find the missing negative. Walter has no means to contact Sean and finds a clue that he might be in Greenland. He decides to travel to Greenland to track Sean down in the beginning of an unbelievable adventure.—Claudio Carvalho, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
name: The Secret Life of Walter Mitty
